content.description: The <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> operon in E. coli is an example of a repressible operon that consists of genes coding for enzymes used to synthesize tryptophan. When tryptophan levels are high, the operon is turned off and these genes are not transcribed. However, it is also known that tryptophan does not bind directly to the operator <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sequence. A regulatory gene called <math alttext="t r p upper case R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has also been discovered although it is not part of the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> operon. The proposed model of how tryptophan acts as a corepressor is shown in Figure 1.
content.question: Figure 1. Model of proposed regulation of the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></math> operon by corepressors <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></math> repressor and tryptophan Which of the following evidence best supports a claim that tryptophan functions as a corepressor?

choices.label: Normal expression of <math alttext="t r p upper case R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> causes the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></math> operon to be transcribed regardless of tryptophan levels.
When the operator sequence is mutated, the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> operon is not transcribed.

The <math alttext="t p r upper case R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene codes for a repressor protein that has a <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> binding domain.

When <math alttext="t r p upper case R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is mutated, the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> operon is transcribed regardless of tryptophan levels.

content.answer: When <math alttext="t r p upper case R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is mutated, the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> operon is transcribed regardless of tryptophan levels.

skill.text: 6.B: Support a claim with evidence from biological principles, concepts, processes, and data.
